Dispute_Type: Liability and limitation of liability in maritime collision
Legal_Issue: Whether Sheena M Interests can obtain a stay of the liability action while pursuing a limitation action
Governing_Law: 1976 Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims
Section 50(1)(b) of the Federal Court Act
Evidence_Assessment: Potential prejudice to Sheena M Interests from concurrent actions
Lack of significant harm to CPR if stay is granted
Decision_Outcome: Stay granted for liability action against all defendants except Rivtow Marine Ltd.
Burden_of_Proof: On Sheena M Interests to demonstrate that a stay is in the interests of justice
Legal_Rule: Shipowners may limit liability under the 1976 Convention unless intentional or reckless fault is proven; courts may grant stays under Section 50(1)(b) of the Federal Court Act if in the interests of justice
Grounds_for_Claim: Collision between tugboat Sheena M and CPR bridge resulting in damage
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided on merits; procedural stay granted
Key_Evidence_Considered: Risk of prejudice to Sheena M Interests
Legal_Framework: 1976 Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims
Defendant_Response: CPR opposed the stay, arguing against disruption of the liability action
Evidence_Type: Legal argument on jurisdiction and procedure
Remedy_Requested: Stay of liability action pending resolution of limitation action
Outcome: Stay granted; liability action paused until limitation action is resolved

Dispute_Type: Collision involving tugboat causing property damage
Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff can limit liability under Section 575 of the Canada Shipping Act
Governing_Law: Section 575 and Section 576 of the Canada Shipping Act
Procedural_Stage: Motion for limitation of liability and stay of proceedings
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavit evidence is weak; navigation error without fault or privity may apply
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to establish right to limitation of liability
Legal_Rule: Shipowner may limit liability to 1,000 gold francs per ton of limitation tonnage unless fault or privity is proven
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and procedural fairness under the Canada Shipping Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Damage caused by tug 'Sea Cap XII' during towing operations
Outcome_on_Merits: Plaintiff allowed to proceed with limitation action subject to conditions
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of collision, tonnage calculation, affidavit evidence on fault
Legal_Framework: Canada Shipping Act, particularly liability limitation provisions
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated, but claimants require security and discovery
Remedy_Requested: Limitation of liability and stay of proceedings
Outcome: Court granted conditional stay requiring provision of security and early discovery
Legal_Provision: Section 575 and Section 576 of the Canada Shipping Act
Authority: Federal court jurisdiction under Canadian maritime law

Legal_Issue: Whether Compulife's expungement application under s. 57 of the Trade-marks Act can be stayed pending its infringement action
Governing_Law: Section 50(1) of the Federal Court Act
Procedural_Stage: Motion to stay or join proceedings
Evidence_Assessment: No clear prejudice or injustice shown by Compuoffice
Decision_Outcome: Motion for stay and joinder dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On Compuoffice to demonstrate prejudice or injustice
Legal_Rule: A stay is granted only if continuation causes prejudice/injustice to the defendant and does not unjustly affect the plaintiff
Outcome_on_Merits: Stay denied; expungement and infringement proceedings to continue separately
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of expungement (in rem) vs. infringement (in personam)
Defendant_Response: Compuoffice filed a motion seeking stay or joinder
Outcome: Motion dismissed; 40-day extension granted to Compuoffice for filing reply evidence

Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights
Legal_Issue: Whether the defendant's action can be stayed until resolution of a related case involving Cummings Point
Governing_Law: s. 50 of the Federal Court Act
Evidence_Assessment: Defendant sold the accused division prior to providing access to records or personnel; plaintiff retains right to examine defendant despite limited information
Burden_of_Proof: On defendant to demonstrate lack of access to necessary information
Legal_Rule: A stay may be granted under s. 50 of the Federal Court Act only if continuing the action causes prejudice or injustice to the defendant and does not harm the plaintiff
Standard_of_Review: Judicial discretion based on risk of prejudice or injustice
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendant sought stay to avoid duplicate proceedings
Outcome_on_Merits: Stay denied; defendant must proceed with discovery
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of sale of accused division, availability of records and personnel
Defendant_Response: Requested stay of proceedings pending outcome of related case
Outcome: Stay denied; defendant allowed extended time for discovery arrangements

Dispute_Type: Alleged discrimination in medical care during incarceration
Legal_Issue: Did the Canadian Human Rights Commission err in dismissing Hartjes's complaint for lack of a prohibited ground of discrimination?
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence to establish a prohibited ground of discrimination
Burden_of_Proof: Complainant failed to provide evidence linking treatment to discrimination
Legal_Rule: s. 41(1)(c) of the Canadian Human Rights Act – Commission has discretion to refuse complaints not based on prohibited grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Allegation of inadequate medical care, lack of evidentiary link to discrimination
Legal_Framework: Federal human rights law, administrative law principles
Evidence_Type: Complaint allegations, absence of supporting evidence
Outcome: Application dismissed, no costs awarded
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Material misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration application refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Officer's refusal of H&C application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant concealed marital status, affecting credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of new evidence beyond IAD consideration
Crimes.Application_Error: Concealment of marital status upon entry
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard for decision, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Waiver of strict compliance if justified

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose change in marital and parental status
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inland visa exemption application refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Officer's refusal under subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: No new evidence provided beyond IAD record
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of visa exemption application upheld
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Prior concealment of marital and parental status
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for decision, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed for lack of new evidence and no procedural unfairness
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No procedural unfairness or bias found

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving personal vs. generalized risk
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Unreasonable determination by the Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Evidence of specific targeting by criminal gang was present but dismissed
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Refusal to pay extortion fees leading to targeted threats
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Personal risk due to specific targeting, not generalized

Crimes.Crime_Name: Police Inaction in the Face of Criminal Activity
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on state inability to protect from criminal extortion
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether risk is personal or generalized under IRPA
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of refugee claim denial
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Specific threats and lack of police protection considered
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial of refugee status by Board
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate personal risk
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant deemed credible and specifically targeted
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Personal risk must be distinct from general population
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution by non-state actors with state complicity or inaction
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Threats from gang, refusal to pay extortion, police failure to act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – administrative decision under review
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit, threat evidence, country condition reports

Crimes.Violation_Type: State failure to protect individuals from organized crime
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 97 - failure to recognize personal risk
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant targeted after refusing extortion demands
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliant with immigration procedures in Canada
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Unreasonable assessment by Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction under IRPA s. 72
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to properly assess individualized risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, remanded for new hearing
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as person in need of protection
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: De novo hearing before new panel
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk was individualized due to specific targeting

Crimes.Victim_Status: Business owner targeted for refusing payment
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Threats of violence following refusal to pay
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to active threats and history of violence
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – direct threats due to specific actions
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of threats and targeting
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed truthful and reliable

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Governance and authority conflict between Chief and councillors
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of court orders through misuse of official documents to remove Harley Frank as Chief
Crimes.Governing_Law: Indian Act and Amended Blood Tribe Custom Election Bylaws
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Contempt proceedings with court interventions, injunctions, and compliance enforcement
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inflammatory documents falsely attributed to Harley Frank were used without verification
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Defendants found in contempt for improper removal process
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to demonstrate violation of court orders
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Documents used were misleading and improperly sourced
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Due process required for tribal leadership removal; unauthorized actions prohibited
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Judicial review of compliance with court orders and procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized use of official processes and false documentation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Removal deemed invalid due to lack of due process
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Falsely attributed documents, court orders, procedural violations
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Tribal election bylaws and federal Indian Act provisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Proceeded with removal despite court injunctions
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, court filings, procedural records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Compliance with court orders and fair hearing
Crimes.Outcome: Contempt purged upon agreement to hold new elections
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Amended Blood Tribe Custom Election Bylaws; Indian Act
Crimes.Authority: Justices Muldoon, Teitelbaum, Joyal, and MacKay

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Conflict over tribal governance and leadership authority
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of court orders regarding Harley Frank's position as Chief
Crimes.Governing_Law: Contempt powers under common law and court procedural rules
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Contempt hearings following non-compliance with injunctions
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Defendants proceeded with unauthorized elections and removal actions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Defendants found in contempt but penalties avoided after compliance
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to prove willful disobedience of court orders
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Repeated defiance of judicial directives undermined court authority
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Contempt occurs when party disobeys or undermines court order
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Clear evidence of non-compliance with judicial orders
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized removal attempts, refusal to cooperate, holding illegal elections
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Contempt confirmed, but purged through corrective actions
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Court orders, motions, hearing transcripts, election records
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Court rules on contempt and injunctive relief
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Initially non-compliant, later agreed to general election
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Enforcement of court orders and cessation of unlawful actions
Crimes.Outcome: No penalties imposed after defendants held new election
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Inherent court power to punish for contempt
Crimes.Authority: Justices Muldoon, Teitelbaum, Joyal, and MacKay

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Filing of supplemental reply affidavit to introduce undertaking by immigration consultant
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Court Immigration and Refugee Protection Rules
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence only bolsters existing claims of incompetence, lacks new factual content
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to demonstrate special circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Undertaking not to practice law does not establish new misconduct
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Special circumstances required for supplemental reply affidavit
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Whether unusual, uncommon, or exceptional circumstances exist
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Incompetence and unauthorized legal practice by immigration consultant
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Undertaking by immigration consultant not to practice law
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Court Rules and case law on affidavit supplementation
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Opposition to admission of supplemental affidavit
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Permission to file supplemental reply affidavit
Crimes.Outcome: Denied with costs awarded against applicants
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Rule 13 of Federal Court Immigration and Refugee Rule

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Admissibility of supplemental reply affidavit regarding immigration consultant’s conduct
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Court Immigration and Refugee Rule 13
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence redundant and fails to meet threshold for exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant did not meet burden of showing exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Conduct already known; no new misconduct revealed
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Supplemental affidavits allowed only under unusual or exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Presence of unusual or exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Immigration consultant acting beyond professional scope
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No change in outcome due to lack of prejudice
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Undertaking not to practice law by consultant

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of dismissal based on consultant conduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Admissibility of undertaking as evidence of misrepresentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Court Rules and standards for judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undertaking does not prove prior misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Rules on admissibility of evidence in immigration judicial reviews
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Consultant misrepresented ability to provide legal services
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of exceptional circumstances and new evidence
Crimes.Application_Error: Attempting to use undertaking to prove past misconduct
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Substantial prejudice affecting fairness of proceedings
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; evidence considered but found insufficient
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing and relevance of new evidence
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged unauthorized practice presented as legal representation

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Civil Contempt
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can an individual be held in contempt for violating a court order prohibiting the sale of counterfeit goods?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Common law principles of contempt of court
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: The court assessed witness testimony, affidavits, and Herson's own admission as credible and sufficient evidence.
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Herson admitted to the sale and evidence was corroborated by witnesses and documents
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Contempt of court occurs when a person violates a clear and unambiguous court order
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Clear and convincing evidence standard applied in civil contempt
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of a specific court order prohibiting sale of counterfeit goods
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Court procedures on enforcement of court orders
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Admitted to selling the counterfeit watch
Crimes.Outcome: Fine of $2,000 or 30 days' incarceration if unpaid; costs awarded on solicitor-client basis
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Inherent jurisdiction of the court to punish contempt

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Intellectual Property Violation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is Martin Herson in contempt of court for selling counterfeit Rolex watches after being served with an order prohibiting such conduct?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Trademark Law and court enforcement powers
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Contempt application following trademark infringement order
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence confirmed the watch was counterfeit and Herson admitted the sale; deemed reliable and conclusive
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Herson found in violation of court order related to trademark protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Direct admission by Herson and forensic verification of counterfeit product
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Under Canadian law, contempt of court occurs when an individual knowingly violates a clear and unambiguous court order
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Sale of counterfeit goods in breach of injunction tied to trademark rights
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Contempt established based on violation of trademark-related injunction
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Trade-marks Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. T-13, and equitable remedies
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Admitted to the sale of the counterfeit watch
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Contempt sanction including fine and costs
Crimes.Outcome: Fine of $2,000 or 30 days in jail; $750 costs plus disbursements awarded
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 55(1) of the Trade-marks Act – remedies for infringement

Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness and incorrect assessment of applicant's chosen occupation
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to assess reliability concerns with documentary evidence
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility, but officer must follow fair process
Credibility_Factor: Documents deemed unreliable without prior notice to applicant
Legal_Rule: Visa officers must assess applicants under their chosen occupation and provide opportunity to respond to document concerns
Grounds_for_Claim: Breach of procedural fairness, failure to assess NOC 4162, lack of notice on document concerns
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; decision found procedurally unfair
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, administrative fairness principles
Defendant_Response: No response detailed; decision made ex parte by visa officer
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remitted to different visa officer
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Regulations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Removal deferral and bias
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Officer's decision and apprehension of bias
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims were speculative or unsupported
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration history, work without authorization, tax non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Limited discretion for deferral in extreme cases
Crimes.Application_Factor: Unauthorized work, tax non-payment, failed immigration applications

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Removal deferral and bias
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Officer's decision to deny deferral
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unauthorized work since 2003, non-reporting of income
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, immigration status, pending family matters
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Pending family matters and request for deferral
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of imminent harm or extreme circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Enforcement as soon as reasonably practicable

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to report income to tax authorities
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Removal deferral based on tax non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of refusal to defer removal due to financial non-compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to report income while working illegally
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On Applicant to show irreparable harm
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Removal orders enforced as soon as practicable
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer found no justification for deferral
Crimes.Authority: Canada Revenue Agency, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to demonstrate ties to home country
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph R117(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and IRPR
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a Nigerian national applying for a work permit; has family and marital ties in Nigeria but plans to reside in Canada for an extended period
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to demonstrate intent to leave Canada after authorized stay
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of strong ties compelling return to Nigeria
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible but insufficient to overcome socio-economic incentives to remain in Canada
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Leave to remain in Canada under work permit
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Socio-economic incentives to stay in Canada outweighed familial ties in Nigeria
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Work permit eligibility dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant has sufficient experience to perform childcare work
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and IRPR
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claimed supervisory experience considered but deemed insufficient
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of hands-on daycare experience despite teaching background
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of IRPA
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable grounds to believe ability to perform work
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and relevance of prior work experience

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Work permit refusal based on qualifications
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant can perform the duties of childcare work
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR), Subsection 200(3)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Visa officer relied on interview notes and application documents
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s indirect supervision experience not equivalent to direct care
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A foreign national must be able to perform the work for which a permit is sought
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation of unreasonable factual finding by visa officer
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Interview notes, lack of direct daycare experience
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Visa officer maintained decision was factually grounded

Risk_Assessment: Danger to the public under s. 115(2)(a)

Legal_Issue: Proper consideration of evidence and procedural fairness
Outcome: Remitted for reassessment of country conditions risk

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Findings upheld except risk assessment
Risk_Nature: Public danger despite no recent convictions

Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider country condition evidence
Evidence_Used: Criminal history, gang affiliation, behavioral patterns
Evidentiary_Deficiency: May 2006 submissions on Sri Lanka ignored
Credibility_Assessment: Pattern of behavior supports danger finding
Outcome: Remitted for risk reassessment

Dispute_Type: Deportation based on drug-related organized crime
Risk_Nexus: Link between past behavior and future danger
Outcome: Risk assessment remitted

Crimes.Crime_Name: Using a firearm to commit an offence
Possession of a weapon dangerous to the public
Risk_Nature: Continuing threat due to criminal pattern

Prior_Criminality: History of criminal and gang activity
Evidence_Credibility: Accepted as part of behavioral pattern

Credibility_Assessment: Reliance on non-conviction incidents found reasonable

Legal_Issue: Whether it was reasonable for the Minister's delegate to deny Mr. Fleet's request for relief from penalties and interest on RRSP over-contributions
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Fleet provided insufficient evidence to support his claim that CRA delays contributed to his failure to file; reliance on advisors was noted but not excused
Decision_Outcome: Denial of relief from penalties and interest was upheld as reasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On the taxpayer to demonstrate extenuating circumstances
Credibility_Factor: Mr. Fleet's claims were partially undermined by lack of supporting evidence
Legal_Rule: Section 220(3.1) allows waiver of penalties/interest if extenuating circumstances exist; taxpayers are accountable for actions of their advisors
Grounds_for_Claim: RRSP over-contribution due to erroneous advice from employer; request for penalty and interest relief
Key_Evidence_Considered: Reliance on financial advisors, missed filing deadlines, failure to submit T1-OVP returns, alleged CRA processing delays
Defendant_Response: Mr. Fleet blamed CRA delays and relied on professional advice, but did not provide sufficient documentation
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, taxpayer testimony, administrative records
Remedy_Requested: Waiver or cancellation of penalties and interest on RRSP over-contributions
Outcome: Application dismissed; no costs awarded due to government error in advising Mr. Fleet
Authority: Minister's delegate, Tax Court of Canada

Legal_Issue: Can the Court issue a nunc pro tunc order to avoid termination of an immigration application under s. 87.4(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Governing_Law: Section 87.4(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Application submitted before February 27, 2008; no decision made by March 29, 2012
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate jurisdictional error or reviewable error
Legal_Rule: Section 87.4(1) terminates applications for permanent resident visas in the federal skilled worker category if not decided by March 29, 2012
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on nature of legal issue
Grounds_for_Claim: Seeking reinstatement via nunc pro tunc order to overcome legislative termination
Outcome_on_Merits: No relief granted; Court lacks jurisdiction to override statutory termination
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of application submission; date of legislative cutoff; status of application processing
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act; principles of administrative law; court jurisdiction
Defendant_Response: Parliament’s intent under s. 87.4(1) is clear and binding; courts cannot extend jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Nunc pro tunc order to reinstate immigration application
Outcome: Application dismissed; no jurisdiction to countermand Parliament's intent
Legal_Provision: s. 87.4(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration and Refugee Protection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer's decision rejecting the applicant's pre-removal risk assessment application was based on reasonable findings of fact and law
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 97
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence of personalized risk in Cuba due to political opinion or homosexuality; mental health concerns deemed speculative and not relevant under section 97
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant did not meet the burden of proof on a balance of probabilities
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible, specific evidence supporting claims of persecution
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Standard of review is reasonableness, assessing justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to political opinion and homosexuality
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of evidence of current targeting by Cuban authorities or mistreatment of family
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – person in need of protection
Crimes.Defendant_Response: PRRA officer found no personalized risk upon return to Cuba
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit, country condition reports, personal testimony (deemed insufficient)
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of general importance and allowance of judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility due to serious non-political crime
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 97
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of a serious non-political crime outside Cuba; claimed risk upon return due to father’s political targeting and her homosexuality
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant with criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – applicant not lawfully resident due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA submission, personal affidavits, country condition information
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate personalized risk linked to s. 97 grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims of risk not supported by objective evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn of PRRA refusal and stay of removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and potential certification of general importance
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Personalized risk of torture, life-threatening danger, or cruel and unusual treatment under s. 97
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not meet burden of proof under s. 97; no evidence of state interest or targeted harm

Crimes.Violation_Type: Refugee ineligibility due to serious non-political crime
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 97(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant’s refugee claim rejected due to conviction for serious non-political crime; subsequent PRRA application filed
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Inadmissible foreign national with prior refugee claim
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA application materials, personal declarations, country conditions in Cuba
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of current persecution or personal targeting by Cuban authorities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims of persecution due to political opinion and homosexuality lacked corroboration
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no certification granted
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Allowance of PRRA, protection from removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Person in need of protection under s. 97 based on personalized risk
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No sufficient evidence to establish risk of torture or cruel and unusual treatment upon return

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Officer's decision
Breach of procedural fairness due to lack of oral interview
Evidence_Assessment: Unverified psychologist's opinion on conditions in Korea
Inference of family support based on past support
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Credibility_Factor: Officer's reasonable inference about family support
Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness does not always require an oral hearing
Standard of review is reasonableness for H&C decisions
Defendant_Response: Officer reasonably assessed hardship and family support
Remedy_Requested: Overturning of refusal of H&C application
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
No certification issued

Crime_Name: Trademark Infringement and Breach of Contract
Dispute_Type: Termination of franchise agreement and continued use of trademarks
Legal_Issue: Whether plaintiffs can obtain an interlocutory injunction for trademark infringement and false representation
Evidence_Assessment: Huron Shores ceased paying fees; dispute over termination notice and compliance
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs must show serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience
Credibility_Factor: Both parties presented credible arguments on the validity of termination and rights to use trademarks
Legal_Rule: Interlocutory injunction requires: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience favoring applicant
Grounds_for_Claim: Trademark infringement post-termination, breach of contract, false representation
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided; case remains open for full trial
Key_Evidence_Considered: Franchise agreement terms, payment history, notice of termination, use of trademarks
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, common law principles of contract and injunctions
Defendant_Response: Claimed breach of contract by plaintiff and sought specific performance
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (contract), financial records, legal notices
Remedy_Requested: Interlocutory injunction to stop trademark use
Outcome: Injunction denied; status quo maintained with Huron Shores depositing 1.5% of gross income or $3,000 into trust account
Legal_Provision: Registered trademark protections, contractual termination clauses
Authority: Court applying equitable doctrines including 'clean hands'

Dispute_Type: Trademark usage and enforcement of official marks
Legal_Issue: Enforceability of official marks under the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence of prior use of SPIRIT BEAR as an official mark
Burden_of_Proof: On public authority to demonstrate adoption and use prior to publication
Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible evidence provided by City of Terrace and Kitasoo Band Council
Legal_Rule: Public authority must show adoption and use of an official mark before publication
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of official mark SPIRIT BEAR
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence (or lack thereof) of use of SPIRIT BEAR for wares or services
Defendant_Response: Defense and counterclaim by Urban Distilleries Inc.
Remedy_Requested: Enforcement of official mark and dismissal of defendant's use
Outcome: Motion dismissed, costs awarded to Urban Distilleries Inc.
Authority: City of Terrace and Kitasoo Band Council

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on persecution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility findings
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of media reports, medical records, lawyer's letter

Crimes.Threat_Source: Government official after assault and threats

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to ongoing threats
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, due to resistance of advances

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim due to property damage and threats
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unreasonable credibility assessment by Board
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Media coverage assumption, medical omissions, lawyer's letter

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to consider reasonable explanations

Legal_Issue: Did the Visa Officer err in refusing the applicant's self-employed person class permanent residency application?
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, subsection 88(1)
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant had full-time employment and lacked sufficient world-class experience
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate eligibility as a self-employed person
Legal_Rule: Applicant must meet the definition of a 'self-employed person' under subsection 88(1), requiring relevant experience and ability to make a significant contribution
Grounds_for_Claim: Contested refusal of permanent resident visa application under the self-employed category
Outcome_on_Merits: Officer’s decision was reasonable and justified
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's employment history and evidence of world-class experience
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Defendant_Response: Visa Officer reasonably concluded applicant did not meet criteria
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of employment and qualifications
Outcome: Court upheld the Officer's decision
Legal_Provision: Subsection 88(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Authority: Federal Court (implied by judicial review context)

Legal_Issue: Whether there was a likelihood of confusion between 'Nature's Source' and 'Natursource' trademarks
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Trade-marks Opposition Board decision to Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Limited evidence of actual confusion due to geographical separation; phonetic and visual resemblance of marks; overlap in nature of services/products
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant (Nature's Source Inc.) to overcome opposition
Credibility_Factor: Length of use favoring Natursource Inc.; distinctiveness of 'Natursource'
Legal_Rule: Likelihood of confusion assessed by considering distinctiveness, length of use, nature of wares/services, trade channels, and resemblance in appearance/sound/ideas
Grounds_for_Claim: Opposition based on likelihood of confusion with prior registered mark 'Natursource'
Outcome_on_Merits: Board's finding of likelihood of confusion was reasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration of use of 'Natursource'; similarity in sound and appearance of marks; overlapping retail and natural health product services
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, specifically s.6(5) of the Trademark Act
Defendant_Response: Nature's Source Inc. sought registration; Natursource Inc. opposed based on prior rights
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, use history, market presence
Outcome: Registration refused; appeal dismissed with costs to respondent

Dispute_Type: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) grounds for immigration exemption
Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer breached the duty of fairness or erred in law during the H&C review
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under s. 82.1(1) of the Immigration Act
Evidence_Assessment: Consideration of marriage genuineness, letters, risk assessments
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate legal error or breach of fairness
Legal_Rule: Duty of fairness requires minimal procedural obligations; no hearing or reasons required unless error in law, improper principle, or bad faith
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in assessing marriage genuineness and failure to consider risk evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: No legal error or breach of fairness found
Key_Evidence_Considered: Letters, risk assessments, evidence of marriage
Legal_Framework: Immigration Act, humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Defendant_Response: Immigration officer considered all evidence and made a reasonable determination
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal declarations, risk reports
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Outcome: Application dismissed; decision upheld
Legal_Provision: s. 114(2), s. 82.1(1) of the Immigration Act

Application_Facts: Mr. El Falah reported conflicting absence periods (391 vs. 351 days); insufficient proof of Canadian residence during claimed periods
Residency_Compliance: Failed to demonstrate physical presence of at least 1095 days over four years
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent reporting of absences indicating potential misrepresentation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Conflicting absence reports, lack of supporting documentation for residency
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship Judge found applicant's evidence inconsistent and unconvincing
Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship application rejection
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of decision and approval of citizenship application
Decision_Rationale: Judge reasonably concluded that Mr. El Falah failed to provide sufficient, credible evidence to meet the residency requirement

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer fettered discretion by failing to consider post-decision establishment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant entered with false passport and remained illegally, affecting credibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations for permanent residence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Voluntary choice to remain in Canada illegally after departure order
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to consider new evidence of establishment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Post-leave establishment due to applicant's deliberate non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Fettering of discretion in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of time in Canada, family ties, employment
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of permanent residence on H&C grounds upheld

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada using a false passport and claimed refugee status
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Remained in Canada without legal status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Use of false passport constitutes misrepresentation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel documents, refugee hearing record, establishment evidence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible explanation for use of false passport
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Serious doubt due to use of fraudulent travel document
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application refused; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of law or setting aside of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer properly exercised discretion; no procedural unfairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to comply with departure order
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refusal of H&C application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether officer failed to fairly assess post-decision establishment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative assessment due to illegal stay after departure order
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Evidence of integration after leave decision
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on establishment
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Voluntary decision to remain in Canada contrary to law
Crimes.Application_Error: Allegation that officer did not consider new evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Post-decision establishment, due to illegality of presence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family ties, employment, length of residence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration violation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Entered with false passport, refugee claim rejected, applied for H&C relief
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to depart after negative refugee decision and departure order
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Use of false passport at entry
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Consideration of new evidence after decision to leave
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's role in reviewing administrative decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Establishment in Canada post-refusal, family and employment records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined by illegal conduct and prior fraud
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No obligation to grant relief due to voluntary illegality
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, Federal Court of Canada

Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and risk of persecution in refugee status determination
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found inconsistencies in applicant's statements and lack of credible evidence
Evidence_Type: Applicant's initial forms, claimed past persecution incidents
Legal_Provision: IRPA - well-founded fear of persecution, inability to integrate due to war or human rights violations
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution, human rights violations
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in reporting, omission of key incidents, perceived economic motivation
Application_Error: Failure to disclose key incidents in initial application forms
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of officer's decision, procedural fairness
Document_Fraud: False or incomplete statements in application forms

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Document authenticity and credibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in rejecting the LP membership card as fraudulent without forensic analysis
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found the Applicant's explanation regarding the incomplete seal unconvincing
Crimes.Evidence_Type: LP membership card with incomplete seal
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section related to document authenticity and refugee claim assessment
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Incomplete seal on the LP membership card indicating possible tampering
Crimes.Application_Error: None found – Board’s decision not patently unreasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's explanation for the incomplete seal
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of specialized knowledge by the Board
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Rejection of document and adverse credibility finding upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Altered or incomplete official seal on membership card

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation in support of refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – Misrepresentation provisions
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant presented an LP membership card with signs of tampering
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claim based on fear of return
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Submission of a document with an incomplete seal without credible explanation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Need for forensic analysis vs. reliance on expert assessment
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of the Board to assess document authenticity
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of forensic testing requested by applicant
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanation for discrepancy not accepted
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Certification of question and overturning of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board used expertise and provided opportunity to respond

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant alleged risk of abduction and extortion due to extended stay in Canada; officer failed to address these risks in PRRA assessment
Procedural_Issue: Officer did not address all risk factors presented by the applicant; decision found procedurally unfair
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Respondent argued insufficient evidence, but officer still had duty to assess all risks regardless of evidentiary support
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; original decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of PRRA application for redetermination by a different officer with opportunity for new submissions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unreasonableness and procedural fairness under subsection 72(1) of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to consider all alleged risks, rendering the decision unreasonable and procedurally unfair
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer responsible for PRRA assessment

Legal_Issue: Breach of principles of natural justice
Governing_Law: Rule 49(1) of the Refugee Protection Division Rules
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; matter referred back for reconsideration
Credibility_Assessment: Doubts raised due to failure to address individual evidence
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to consider unique circumstances of each applicant
Application_Error: Dismissal based on common factors without individual analysis
Decision_Outcome: Remanded to a different panel for new hearing

Legal_Issue: Adequacy of reasons for immigration application denial
Outcome: Decision set aside, case referred back for re-determination
Legal_Provision: Procedural fairness requirements in immigration decisions
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient assessment of applicant's experience and lack of detailed reasoning
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of adequate reasons provided by visa officer
Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient reasons for denial
Assessment_Standard: Sufficiency of reasons and compliance with procedural fairness
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's experience as not adequately assessed
Decision_Outcome: Immigration application denied initially, overturned on judicial review

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Applicant does not speak English; interpreter errors affected key factual details such as dates and actions (e.g., 'pulled' vs. 'carried'); errors influenced credibility findings
Evidence_Used: Transcript of hearing, expert affidavit on interpretation quality
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate interpretation leading to factual inaccuracies in the record
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding by the Board influenced by interpreter errors
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by the Board
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, overturned decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee status denial
Legal_Standard_Applied: Right to a fair hearing under s. 14 of the Charter
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with correctness for Charter issues
Decision_Rationale: Interpreter errors violated the applicant's right to a fair hearing, undermining the reliability of the credibility assessment
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) determination
Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed
Evidence_Type: Evidence of violence against new arrivals in Abuja
Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) of the IRPA, IFA test components
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by MEND in Nigeria
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of a serious possibility of danger in the proposed IFA location
Application_Error: Failure to address contradictory evidence on safety in Abuja
Assessment_Standard: Relocation must be reasonable; second branch reviewed for reasonableness
Evidence_Ignored: Reports of violence against internally displaced persons and new arrivals in Abuja
Legal_Standard: Two-part IFA test: (1) no serious possibility of persecution (correctness), (2) reasonable relocation conditions (reasonableness)
Application_Factor: Mobility rights, lack of family ties in Abuja
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision set aside, remanded to a different panel for reconsideration
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for persecution branch, reasonableness for relocation conditions

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee protection due to threats from a paramilitary group after her partner's death
Procedural_Issue: RPD found inconsistencies in debt amount, complaint details, and behavior post-threat
Applicant argued breach of procedural fairness

Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant's testimony inconsistent and lacking credibility
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness occurred
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
RPD's decision upheld
Decision_Rationale: Inconsistencies in key aspects of the claim undermined credibility
No errors in process or reasoning by RPD

Violation_Type: Failure to meet skilled worker requirements
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Application_Facts: Applicant's work experience classified under NOC 1431, which does not fall under Skill Type O/A/B; promotion occurred after application period
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness due to decision before deadline for additional documents
Evidence_Used: Work experience documentation, NOC classification, application timeline
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of qualifying skilled work experience during application period
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness under IRPA, assessment under IRPR subsection 75(3)
Decision_Rationale: Additional documents would not have changed outcome; no breach of procedural fairness as decision was substantively justified

Crimes.Crime_Name: Engaging in activities contrary to the Criminal Code's terrorism definition
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: The applicant was assessed as posing a security threat due to membership in organizations engaged in terrorism.
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in FPMR and Milices rodriguistes, groups involved in terrorist acts.
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Acts of terrorism committed by FPMR and Milices rodriguistes.
Crimes.Target_Entity: Chilean government during the dictatorship period.
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant admitted membership in FPMR and Milices rodriguistes.
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: High, based on applicant’s admissions and supporting evidence.
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Credibility of applicant's admissions and documentation on group activities.
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's admissions credible and consistent with evidence.
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 34(1)(c) and (f)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Permanent residence application denied; judicial review dismissed

Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Membership in known terrorist organizations during Chilean dictatorship deemed a security risk.
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Affiliation with FPMR and Milices rodriguistes linked to terrorism.
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Terrorist acts including violence and subversion during political conflict.
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant admitted membership in both organizations.
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: High, supported by applicant’s admissions and historical records.
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliability of foreign-source intelligence and personal admissions.
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Admissions treated as reliable; no indication of coercion or inconsistency.
Credibility_Factors: Alignment with known facts about the groups
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 34(1)(c) and (f)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility confirmed; application for permanent residence denied

Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Active participation in organizations that carried out violent and subversive acts.
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in FPMR, Milices rodriguistes, and MIR—all associated with armed resistance.
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Violent political actions, including attacks and insurgency activities.
Crimes.Target_Entity: Government and state apparatus of Chile under dictatorship
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant admitted involvement with all three organizations.
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Strong, based on direct admissions and contextual evidence.
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Extent of individual participation versus general membership.
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Admissions considered truthful and detailed enough to support findings.
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 34(1)(c) and (f)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Decision upheld; applicant remains inadmissible to Canada

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant re-entered Canada after deportation and reported home break-ins and threats from Delroy Wright

Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to re-entry after deportation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer failed to clearly analyze whether evidence constituted new information under section 113

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; issue was procedural evaluation
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside

Violation_Type: Failure to consider compelling reasons exception
Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 108(1)(e) and Subsection 108(4), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Application_Facts: Mr. Decka claimed persecution in Albania due to political opinion; Board found no current well-founded fear or need for protection due to changed country conditions; no explicit finding of past persecution
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure by the Refugee Protection Division to consider the 'compelling reasons' exception under subsection 108(4) when grounds for protection ceased to exist
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports indicating changes in Albania
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of explicit finding on past persecution
Decision_Outcome: No error found in Board’s decision
Outcome: Application dismissed
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the negative refugee determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of paragraphs 108(1)(e) and 108(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Rationale: The Board had no obligation to consider compelling reasons under subsection 108(4) because it did not find past persecution; the cessation of protection grounds was justified based on changed country conditions
